title: Fundamentals of Risk Management and Resource Evaluation
headline: Free online course on risk management, resource allocation, software quality, as well as PERT and Maslow’s Hierarchy.
description: This free online course on Risk Management and Resource Evaluation provides a comprehensive guide on how you can manage risks and allocate appropriate resources to projects. You will learn about organizational and team structures, as well as project crashing. You will also learn about different categories and phases of resource allocation. Start this course today to learn more about risk management and resource evaluation in project management.

courseDescription:
This free online course on Risk Management and Resource Evaluation will begin by introducing you to PERT and project crashing. You will learn about how PERT uses three probabilistic time estimates for activities and how the duration of a project is reduced through the process of project crashing. You will learn about Maslow’s hierarchy of needs with regards to employee motivation and how Herzberg’s 2 Factor Theory affects job satisfaction. You will also study the characteristics of the organisation and team structure as well as their advantages and disadvantages.

This course will then discuss team structure and risk management. You will learn about the chief programmer team, democratic team and hierarchical team. You will learn about the different categories of risk such as market risk, financial risk, project risk and technological risk as well as how to manage them. You will then be introduced to the importance of having quality software products that satisfy the requirements specified in the SRS document.

Lastly, this course will introduce you to the concept of resource allocation. You will learn about the categories of resources; labour, equipment, materials, space, services, time and money. You will learn about the importance of identifying resource requirements and how to prepare a resource requirement list. This course will present the different phases of resource allocation as well as teach you how to maximize the percentage usage of resources. Start this course today and learn more about risk management and resource evaluation in software project management.

Start Course Now

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to organizational structure and risk management. You will learn about PERT and project crashing as well as team management. You will also learn about the typical organizational structures and team structures. This module will also introduce risk management, as well as software quality.
topics: Organizational Structure and Risk Management - Learning Outcomes
Risk Management and Introduction to Software Quality
Organisational Structure and Risk Management - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to resource evaluation. You will learn about the different categories of resource allocation as well as the different phases of resource allocation. You will also be introduced to the outcomes of resource allocation, how to publish the resource schedule using a work schedule, as well as how to present cost schedules.

modules.name: Module
topics: Fundamentals of Risk Management and Resource Evaluation  - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • List the three probabilistic time estimates PERT uses for each activity. 
    • Describe the responsibilities of the project manager when it comes to managing a team project.
    • Describe how Maslow’s hierarchy of needs relates to an individual’s motivation.
    • Analyze Herzberg’s 2 factor theory with regards to job satisfaction.
    • Discuss the methods for improving job satisfaction.
    • List the typical organisational structures along with their advantages and disadvantages.
    • Identify the role of a chief programmer.
    • Identify the framework for dealing with risk.
    • Define fitness of purpose with regards to software products.
  • Probabilistic Time Estimates and Project Crashing

  • A Framework for Proactive Risk Management

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • A Framework for Proactive Risk Management

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary 
    • PERT incorporates variabilities in activity durations into task network analysis.
    • PERT uses three-time estimates for each activity: most likely time, optimistic time, and pessimistic time.
    • Project crashing reduces the duration of the critical task by deploying more resources for the task.
    • Managing a team project consists of tracking team members performance, motivating team members, providing timely feedback, and resolving issues and conflicts.
    • Maslow’s hierarchy of needs suggests that as a lower level of needs is satisfied, gradually a higher level of needs will emerge.
    • Maslow’s hierarchy of needs consists of physiological needs, safety needs, social needs, esteem needs and self-actualization.
    • Herzberg’s two-factor theory suggested that two sets of factors affect job satisfaction; maintenance factors and motivators.
    • Methods for improving job satisfaction include; setting specific goals, providing feedback on progress towards meeting those goals and considering job redesign (job enlargement, job enrichment).
    • Typical organisational structures are a functional organization, project organisation and matrix organisation.
  • Lesson Summary 
    • PERT incorporates variabilities in activity durations into task network analysis.
    • PERT uses three-time estimates for each activity: most likely time, optimistic time, and pessimistic time.
    • Project crashing reduces the duration of the critical task by deploying more resources for the task.
    • Managing a team project consists of tracking team members performance, motivating team members, providing timely feedback, and resolving issues and conflicts.
    • Maslow’s hierarchy of needs suggests that as a lower level of needs is satisfied, gradually a higher level of needs will emerge.
    • Maslow’s hierarchy of needs consists of physiological needs, safety needs, social needs, esteem needs and self-actualization.
    • Herzberg’s two-factor theory suggested that two sets of factors affect job satisfaction; maintenance factors and motivators.
    • Methods for improving job satisfaction include; setting specific goals, providing feedback on progress towards meeting those goals and considering job redesign (job enlargement, job enrichment).
    • Typical organisational structures are a functional organization, project organisation and matrix organisation.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss how to match the activity plan to available resources.
    • List the categories of resources for a project.
    • Define the purpose of a resource requirements list.
    • Discuss the processes of scheduling resources.
    • Discuss the allocation of resources to individuals and the factors to be considered during allocation.
    • Describe how to represent cost schedules.
    • Discuss the scheduling process.
  • Nature and Categories of Resources

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Nature and Categories of Resources

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Resource Scheduling, Histogram and Smoothing

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Resource Scheduling, Histogram and Smoothing

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Resource Schedule and Cost Schedule

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Resource Schedule and Cost Schedule

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary 
    • The final result of resource allocation will be a number of schedules such as; activity schedule, resource scheduling, and cost schedule.
    • Categories of resources include labour, equipment, materials and space, services, time and money.
    • The resource requirements in a software development project are to identify hardware, software and support.
    • A resource list contains the resources that will be required along with the expected level of demand.
    • Scheduling of resources entails mapping the resources requirements to an activity plan to assess the distribution of resources required over the duration of the project.
    • The activity plan is carried out on a bar chart to produce resources histogram.
    • Resource smoothing means having a constant number of employees working on a project on a continuous block of time.
    • Resource clashes happen when the same resources are needed in more than one place at the same time.
    • Prioritizing activities is important in order to allocate resources to critical path activities.
    • Project managers should allocate individual members of staff to activities as early as possible.
    • Factors affecting the allocation of individuals to tasks include availability, criticality, risk, training, and team building.
    • A cost schedule shows the weekly or monthly costs over the life of the project.
